Award.AwardTitle: Forward Fitting Methods for Radio Spectral Diagnostics of Solar Flares
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will develop new methods for the analysis of imaging radio spectroscopy data. These methods will provide reliable tools for diagnosing fast particle and plasma parameters in solar flares, one of the key objectives of imaging radio spectroscopy.

The project will develop theoretical models involving particle acceleration, energy-dependent and angle-dependent particle losses, and pitch-angle anisotropy modifications (due to both angular diffusion and anisotropic transport effects). Models of nonthermal radio emission will be constructed to include relevant emission and absorption processes (primarily gyrosynchrotron and free-free emission/absorption), as well as other coherent and incoherent processes. These models will be tested for self-consistency and applied to high-resolution data as available. In particular, the PI will carefully examine high spatial resolution solar flare observations from the Nobeyama Radioheliograph in Japan and high spectral resolution data from the Owens Valley Solar Array in California.

This effort will provide reliable forward-fitting models needed to analyze currently available radio data and to maximize the scientific return from new radio instruments in development, such as the Frequency-Agile Solar Radiotelescope (FASR) and the Expanded Very Large Array (EVLA). The broader impacts of this work will include dissemination of new knowledge concerning the processes of astrophysical energy release and charged particle acceleration. The studies will be performed at the Center for Solar-Terrestrial Research (CSTR) at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, advancing discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning in a diverse university setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Achievements of the project include new computer codes, simulation tools, theory of particle acceleration and radiation from solar flares, and detailed analysis of observational data, offering new deep insight into physics of solar flares. In particular, recently, we proposed a theory explaining mysterious sub-THz component observed from a number of strong solar flares. We proposed that Cherenkov emission from chromospheric levels is fully consistent with all observational demands of the required emission process, which implies more ways of studying the chromospheric state during flares. Besides the solar case, the developed spike decomposition techniques can be applied for analysis of coherent emissions from stars and planets including various terrestrial radiations. New regimes of fast particle acceleration and transport are of great interest throughout astrophysics. The developed remote turbulence sensing is highly relevant to many nonthermal astrophysical sources. Graduate students were educated to use those new tools in their everyday research; two students wrote and published peer-reviewed articles in top-ranked scientific journals. Models of radio emission from flares, developed within the project, justified feasibility and urgent need for significant upgrade of the existing imaging radio instrument, Owens Valley Solar Array. This upgrade is now underway with a separate MRI-R2 NSF funding (PI – Dale Gary). A summer student from University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign was trained during summer 2010 within REU supplement to this grant. The project outcome is documented in 18 articles in scientific journals, which have garnered more than 50 citations.
